messages: cdc90963b9400a427d6dcb8685256e1d (01:58): how can i set an environment variable from within Vim?
4969e383a78d3407b54160eb0de4b90b (01:58): Environment variables are private to a process. Child processes inherit them from their parent, but nothing else can change them
ded01cf47cdca62f9adcfd25cb1b3127 (02:00): yet again, LeoNerd is wrong
4969e383a78d3407b54160eb0de4b90b (02:00): Hmm...? Would you like to contradict it?
cdc90963b9400a427d6dcb8685256e1d (02:01): LeoNerd: of course a process can change its variables
ded01cf47cdca62f9adcfd25cb1b3127 (02:01): man 3 setenv
4969e383a78d3407b54160eb0de4b90b (02:01): Yes, it can change its own...
4969e383a78d3407b54160eb0de4b90b (02:01): It can't change its parents..
cdc90963b9400a427d6dcb8685256e1d (02:01): LeoNerd: this is what i want to do! ;)
4969e383a78d3407b54160eb0de4b90b (02:01): I'm just used to most people wanting to change their shell's variables from some program they run within it
cdc90963b9400a427d6dcb8685256e1d (02:02): goflyapig: yes, i tried...
4969e383a78d3407b54160eb0de4b90b (02:02): I guess I misunderstood the question then
cdc90963b9400a427d6dcb8685256e1d (02:02): ...but it set the envvar to 0! :o
cdc90963b9400a427d6dcb8685256e1d (02:03): how can i f.e. append "/usr/local/bin" to $PATH from within Vim?
4969e383a78d3407b54160eb0de4b90b (02:05): :let $PATH = "/usr/local/bin" . $PATH
4969e383a78d3407b54160eb0de4b90b (02:05): :let $PATH = "/usr/local/bin:" . $PATH
4969e383a78d3407b54160eb0de4b90b (02:05): even, to ensure it has right syntax,

97b8d50a76b69ccc832f2964ac5ce569 (02:06): I'm using the zipPlugin to read tar files, but can't figure out how to get it to work recursively.  eg. I have tarball A.tar nested inside tarball B.tar.  I can vim B.tar and it shows me the file listing in  B.tar, but when I try to open A.tar from there it just shows the binary tar file rather than invoking the zipPlugin to show a directory listing.  Anyone tried this yet?
cdc90963b9400a427d6dcb8685256e1d (02:08): oh, how stupid! the spaces are mandatory! :(
cdc90963b9400a427d6dcb8685256e1d (02:08): LeoNerd: thank you! ;)
4969e383a78d3407b54160eb0de4b90b (02:08): Spaces are mandatory.. where?
4969e383a78d3407b54160eb0de4b90b (02:08): :let $PATH="foo:bar:".$PATH
0b2d182efae23710a3f4f438e1744306 (02:08): how do i search case insnsitive?
4969e383a78d3407b54160eb0de4b90b (02:09): :he 'ignorecase
0b2d182efae23710a3f4f438e1744306 (02:09): if i type "/pack" i want to find Pack and pack
828997d3329f6368569d69d0d2baa3e6 (02:09): stu: or for a one off search, prefix the pattern with \c
0b2d182efae23710a3f4f438e1744306 (02:09): LeoNerd: yeah /i is what i tried
0b2d182efae23710a3f4f438e1744306 (02:10): thanks guys

ef30187abedc12d0a3eac45f830e804f (02:30): Hello, does anybody know how to make Vim suggest methods of e.g. vector temlate? I tried omnicompletion, but I'm araid I can't configure it to do so
4969e383a78d3407b54160eb0de4b90b (02:36): Hrm... templates require quite a lot of special C++ parsing code...
4969e383a78d3407b54160eb0de4b90b (02:36): I don't know vim7 very well, but it's quite possible there isn't enough C++ parsing code to cope with them
ef30187abedc12d0a3eac45f830e804f (02:40): LeoNerd I was afraid of that... do you know any development tool that is able to do it (under linux)
fa92dbf68a4d779204a8f09d9af0b7ff (02:41): Try jedit
fa92dbf68a4d779204a8f09d9af0b7ff (02:42): vim isn't really made for programming completion
828997d3329f6368569d69d0d2baa3e6 (02:44): bpuzon: you might try http://icomplete.sf.net although it didn't quite work right for me.
828997d3329f6368569d69d0d2baa3e6 (02:44): eKo1: what is omnicomplete for, if not for programming completion?
fa92dbf68a4d779204a8f09d9af0b7ff (02:45): I think you can use it for all kinds of completion.
fa92dbf68a4d779204a8f09d9af0b7ff (02:45): But I don't use vim for that though.

ded01cf47cdca62f9adcfd25cb1b3127 (03:22): or ~
362ac22683e4eb6a6857848784dd994a (03:22): Macca`, can i do cd/file/inside/current/directory?
ded01cf47cdca62f9adcfd25cb1b3127 (03:22): er, . rather
362ac22683e4eb6a6857848784dd994a (03:23): ok, let me ask this again
362ac22683e4eb6a6857848784dd994a (03:23): i'm editing /Volumes/www/spectadium/admin/menu.php
362ac22683e4eb6a6857848784dd994a (03:23): and i want to open /Volumes/www/spectadium/admin/menu.tpl
362ac22683e4eb6a6857848784dd994a (03:23): without having to write /Volumes/www/spectadium/admin/
ddc67b2db923164e5d8c47d2183fdd21 (03:23): :cd /Volumes/www/spectadium/admin
ddc67b2db923164e5d8c47d2183fdd21 (03:24): then :e menu.tpl
362ac22683e4eb6a6857848784dd994a (03:24): qharris, is that permenent?
362ac22683e4eb6a6857848784dd994a (03:24): (just makin sure)
ddc67b2db923164e5d8c47d2183fdd21 (03:24): when u cd somewhere... u stay there til u quit vim
ddc67b2db923164e5d8c47d2183fdd21 (03:24): (or cd elsewhere)
362ac22683e4eb6a6857848784dd994a (03:24): qharris, awsome

ebe1878ef1fbd8b60c6a86ce071c3658 (03:25): (or maybe 5k of them)
ddc67b2db923164e5d8c47d2183fdd21 (03:25): cd is built into vim, im pretty sure... not all terminal commands are, but you can get a shell with :sh
ebe1878ef1fbd8b60c6a86ce071c3658 (03:26): because I tend to forget them too often :p
ddc67b2db923164e5d8c47d2183fdd21 (03:26): that will drop you into a shell, and you "exit" from there to get back to vim
